posts.cooked:
Hi, our robot is fully functional when we connect to RIO via USB, but we cannot reach RIO when we connect to the new radio’s 2.4. I scanned all the IPs from 10.TE. AM .0 to 10.TE. AM .255 and only the radio and the laptop showed up. We also double-checked all the team numbers. This is the error we get:

Warning ﻿﻿ 44002 ﻿﻿ Ping Results: ﻿link-bad﻿, DS radio(.4)-bad﻿, robot radio(.1)-GOOD﻿, roboRIO(.2)-bad﻿, FMS -bad

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked:
The message you are seeing in the driver station indicates that it cannot ping the roboRIO at 10.TE. AM .2.

Can you connect to the roboRIO via USB and navigate to the web configuration page at 172.22.11.2. Please screenshot that page and post it here.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.custom_user_title: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
hakgun:

We also double-checked all the team numbers.

How did you do this? The most common reason for a robot to connect via USB but not Ethernet or wireless is that the tam number wasn’t set after imaging a roboRIO 2. Imaging your roboRIO 2 — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

Checking the roboRIO webpage will confirm that by following FletcherS7’s instructions.

link_counts.title: Imaging your roboRIO 2 — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked: I have no clue. I re-setted all the team numbers multiple times out of desperation and it didn’t help.
I will have to send the screenshot tomorrow as we have recently left the workshop.

posts.name: Andrew Todd
posts.cooked:
2.4 on these new radios was a HUGE headache for us. We were never able to get them working relatively. Once we put our backup in AP mode like they recommend, we stopped having issues.

I wish that their 2.4Ghz implementation wasn’t so bad…

FletcherS7:

Please screenshot that page and post it here.

These are all the settings of roboRIO.

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked:
Well I can see from the roboRIO settings that the RIO is not connected to anything via ethernet.

Can you please check the connections between the RIO and the VH-109

Can you also navigate to the status page on the VH-109 located at http://10.TE.AM.1/status and screenshot that page as well.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.custom_user_title: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.cooked:
image 508×607 36.7 KB Also the roboRIO light on the radio is blinking.

image 508×607 36.7 KB

image 508×607 36.7 KB
We just tested 2 other ethernet cables and connected the radio through the radio power module and it still doesn’t work.

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked:
Looks like your roboRIO is not getting DHCP from the radio. It’s likely you have a bad ethernet cable or RPM between the RIO and the radio.

I would suggest swapping these cables.

Do you see any link lights on the RIO port on the VH-109 or on the ethernet port on the roboRIO?
